content: The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, outlining goals, objectives, and criteria for the preservation of national natural and cultural heritage. The National Park Service plays a crucial role in preserving our national natural and cultural heritage. Detailed criteria are used to determine which resources should be included in the National Park System, ensuring adequate representation of various resource types. This includes identifying aspects of the national heritage that are adequately represented in existing parks and protected areas. The National Park Service plays a crucial role in preserving our national natural and cultural heritage by identifying aspects of the national heritage that are adequately represented in existing parks and protected areas. Priorities include adding themes and types of resources to provide a more complete representation of our nation's heritage. The role of the National Park Service includes the preservation of natural areas. The National Park Service aims to add themes and resources to provide a more complete representation of the nation's heritage. This includes preserving natural areas, industrial America, nonphysical cultural resources, and offering outdoor recreation opportunities. The plan also defines units of the National Park System and distinguishes between units, affiliated areas, and other areas within the system. The National Park Service plans to add themes and resources to represent the nation's heritage, including natural areas, industrial America, and cultural resources. The plan also defines units of the National Park System and consults with various stakeholders during preparation. The Secretary will consult with organizations and interested parties, including public review and comment opportunities. The plan will be transmitted to Congress within three fiscal years of enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to determine if there are better management alternatives, including partnerships with States, local governments, and the private sector. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated, considering factors like duplication within the system. The Secretary will review the National Park System to identify areas for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management. Factors considered include duplication, resource significance, feasibility, cost, visitor accessibility, collaboration for resource protection, and compatibility with the Park Service's mission. The Secretary will review the National Park System to identify areas for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management based on factors like resource significance, collaboration for resource protection, and compatibility with the Park Service's mission. Recommendations for management by another agency will be made for areas where termination is recommended, with feasible alternatives considered to protect resources and ensure public access. Prior to listing an area for potential modification or termination of National Park Service management, the Secretary must identify feasible alternatives to protect resources and ensure public access. Consultation with various agencies and stakeholders is required, with opportunities for public review and comment. The Secretary must transmit the final list to Congress within one year. The Secretary must consult with various organizations and stakeholders, including public review and comment opportunities, before transmitting recommendations to Congress within one year. The Secretary must consult with organizations and stakeholders before submitting recommendations to Congress within one year regarding modifications or termination of National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission if Secretary fails to transmit report within 1-year period specified in section 102, National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units for more appropriate management alternatives. Commission to prepare and transmit report to House and Senate committees within one year of establishment. The Commission will prepare and transmit a report to Congress listing National Park System units where management should be modified or terminated, considering specified factors. Suggestions for alternative management by entities other than the National Park Service will be provided for areas of national significance. The Commission will suggest alternative management for listed areas of national significance, consulting with various agencies and officials to ensure resource protection and public access. The Commission will consult with federal, state, and local officials, as well as other organizations, to develop a list of areas of national significance for alternative management. The Commission will consist of 7 members familiar with the National Park System. The Commission consists of 7 members with substantial familiarity with the National Park System. Three members are appointed by the Secretary, two by the Speaker of the House, and two by the President Pro Tem of the Senate. The Commission elects a chair from among its members. The Commission consists of 7 members appointed by different officials. The Commission elects a chair from among its members, and vacancies do not affect its functions. A simple majority constitutes a quorum for meetings held at least quarterly. The Commission shall promptly fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. A simple majority of members constitutes a quorum for meetings held at least quarterly or upon the call of the chair or majority. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses for official business. The Commission established under this section shall terminate 90 days after submitting the report to Congress. The Commission may hire staff, with no more than half being current National Park Service employees. Staff are entitled to travel expenses for official business. The Commission may hire staff to carry out its responsibilities, with no more than half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission can also procure temporary services as needed. The Commission may hire staff, with half being National Park Service employees, and can also procure temporary services. The Commission has the power to hold public hearings, make bylaws, rules, and regulations. The Commission has the authority to hold public hearings, make bylaws, rules, and regulations, and use the United States mails. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission has the authority to take actions authorized by this section, use the United States mails, and request relevant information from the Secretary regarding specific plans and duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by inserting "General Authority.--" after "(a)", striking sentences two through seven of subsection (a), and redesignating the last sentence as subsection (e) with the title "Authorization of Appropriations.--". The Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by redesignating subsection (a) and inserting an Authorization of Appropriations. Subsection (b) is removed, and a new subsection (b) is added for Studies of Areas for Potential Addition. The Secretary must annually submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the House of Representatives and the Senate. Consideration is given to areas with national significance, suitability, and feasibility, with special attention to themes, sites, and resources not already included. The Secretary considers areas with national significance, suitability, and feasibility for inclusion in the National Park System. Special attention is given to themes, sites, and resources not already represented. No new studies for inclusion can be initiated without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 prohibits new studies for potential inclusion in the National Park System without specific authorization from Congress. The Act allows the National Park Service to conduct preliminary assessments, gather data, provide assistance, and complete surveys for areas requiring less than $25,000 in expenditure. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 allows the National Park Service to provide technical and planning assistance, process nominations, update studies, and complete surveys for areas requiring less than $25,000 in expenditure. The Secretary must complete the study for each area for potential inclusion in the National Park System within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. The Secretary must complete the study for each area for potential inclusion in the National Park System within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement and consideration of national significance. The Secretary must conduct a study to determine if an area has nationally significant natural or cultural resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and is a suitable addition to the National Park System. Factors considered include resource rarity, integrity, threats, and existing protections. The study for potential additions to the National Park System considers factors such as resource rarity, threats, existing protections, public use potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and long-term resource protection. The study for potential additions to the National Park System considers factors such as resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and long-term resource protection. It also evaluates whether National Park Service management or alternative protection by other agencies or the private sector is appropriate for the area, and identifies the most effective and efficient alternatives for protecting significant resources. The study for potential additions to the National Park System evaluates factors like resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public support. It also determines if National Park Service management or alternative protection by other agencies or the private sector is suitable for the area. The Director of the National Park Service provides a recommendation on the preferred management option for the area to Congress. The Secretary submits a list of areas for potential addition to the National Park System to Congress, considering cultural/historical and natural resources in order of priority. The preferred management option for each area is recommended by the Director of the National Park Service. The Secretary submits a prioritized list of areas for potential addition to the National Park System to Congress, considering cultural/historical and natural resources. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994.
